paragraphs.text: Now that white people have declared 'bae' over, black people can use it in peace.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: "bae" only made its way to mainstream parlance in the last few years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it is a word that most black folk have been intimately familiar with for decades
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Its etymology was unclear
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: its meanings and nuances are deeply understood in context
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "What's up, bae?""That's my bae," etc , have been ways of staking claim and announcing intimacy between oneself and one's (sometimes prospective) lover
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Bae is also used as a term of endearment and affection for someone with whom there is no romantic involvement or interest (not unlike "honey" or "sweetheart" is used in Southern dialogue), as in "Hey bae, can you pass me that plate?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And then Pharrell put it in a song, Miley Cyrus did a cameo, and it gained the attention of mainstream media
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Suddenly there were articles attempting to define the word "bae"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: otherwise reputable businesses began implementing "bae" in their social media ad campaigns
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: everybody and they mama started using it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: At which point it was declared overused by organs of upper-class white folk media like Time magazine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Fair enough: white people's adoption of the term distorted it to the point of misuse and meaninglessness
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What was once a word born of the beautifully eclectic black Southern laziness of the tongue and a shortened version of baby, became a catchall term for anything from inanimate objects to food
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The reference to affection was consistent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: bae was used to describe everything from one's (desired or actual) significant other to pancakes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "That's bae", a student swooned, glancing at a picture of J Cole during a discussion of black masculinity last summer in class
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: "These cupcakes are bae", I read in a Facebook post attached to a picture of a delicious-looking dessert not many months later
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And just like that, the shelf life of bae in the public imagination expired
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the gatekeepers of mainstream language decided that it must be banned
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cultural appropriation at its best, steals, reduces, overuses and then disposes of words like so much bathwater
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The linguist Jane H Hill defines language appropriation as "a type of complex cultural borrowing that involves a dominant group's 'theft' of aspects of a target group's language."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Hill claims that the 'theft' adds value to white identity while further marginalizing nondominant groups
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: This cultural "borrowing" of black language and phraseology happens regularly, allowing non-black folk to "try on" black culture through the use of African American English vernacular and slang without having to "put on" the cultural consequences of actually being black in a culture conditioned to devalue and dismiss it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As Hill claims, language appropriation is further problematic because it gives dominant groups control over the language
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Dominant groups get to decide, for example, when and if certain words are worth appropriation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: when and how the words should be used
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and then when the word becomes cliche, overused and therefore passe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And often in the process, as happened with "bae", the dominant group ends up changing the meaning or pronunciation of words entirely
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The good news is that black language is resilient
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: black folk are creative
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even when the dominant culture tries to dispose of the terms it wears out, other words and phrases will emerge
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We already know some of them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Already you can see terms grounded in communities ("bye Felicia"), disguised in pronunciation ("ratchet"), or invented from imagination ("on fleek") slipping into mainstream and popular culture lexicons (again)
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There, they will be mass produced for financial gain (again), and eventually disposed of (again)
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So, what happens when mainstream culture decides to dispose of a word stolen from black language and then used to the point of saturation in popular culture?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nothing
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The word may lose its novelty so that those who appropriated it stop saying or using it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the word won't disappear or lose its utility in the black community
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We will go on saying bae
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We will say it to our lovers in casual moments at home, and to our children to be endearing
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We will say it in the grocery store, at the movie theatre and across church pews on Sunday mornings as a substitute for names
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We will say it to each other - as we have always done- lovingly, reverently and mindfully
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And with any luck, the word will settle back into its original meaning, sans the unsolicited remix of dominant white culture
paragraphs.label: assumption
